issue.title: Assertion failed! rpcwallet.cpp Line 3838

events.body:
For reference, this is the code:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v0.19.1/src/wallet/rpcwallet.cpp#L3828-L3845

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/58ba7c314d552cea8cb024960a8504577aee586f/src/wallet/rpcwallet.cpp#L3828-L3845

> It looks like you have duplicated addresses in your wallet.
> 
> ```
> // CWallet::mapAddressBook is not expected to contain duplicate
> // address strings, but build a separate set as a precaution just in
> // case it does.
> bool unique = addresses.emplace(address).second;
> ```
> 
> How did you import the addresses/scripts?

I imported it with importMulti , but maybe ran it multiple times, how I could check it?
Anyways, if you import again the same address or privkey, bitcoin core shouldn't add it again if it is already in the wallet

Looking at the code https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/18944#issuecomment-626678678, it seems like this should only happen if there are two CTxDestination objects that don't compare equal but do have the same EncodeDestination string representation. Am I misreading or is the something known to happen?
I created a new wallet with these 30k address and I can correctly run the rpc command, but IDK why could be repeated address or keys in a wallet file created with same bitcoin core
@ryanofsky This happens at least in the case of two malformed `WitnessUnknown` and/or a `CTxNoDestination`, right?
All of them map to an empty string
Though, it should be impossible to import malformed WitnessUnknown, see #18974
Could this be caused by a corrupted bdb file?

issue.title: Sqlite wallet storage
issue.body:
This has been brought up a few times since at least 2018, e.g. [here](http://www.erisian.com.au/meetbot/bitcoin-core-dev/2018/bitcoin-core-dev.2018-09-27-19.00.log.html#l-180), [here](http://www.erisian.com.au/meetbot/bitcoin-core-dev/2018/bitcoin-core-dev.2018-12-14-19.01.log.html#l-96), but I never bothered to open an issue.

Some cherry-picked arguments in favor:

> 19:47:38 <cfields> sqlite is also nice in that they provide a monolithic source file and encourage direct integration.

> 19:54:05 <wumpus> integrating sqlite into a project is trivial, indeed can be done as a single .cpp file if that's desirable

> 19:54:33 <promag> any reason to not consider postgres for instance?
> 19:54:38 <wumpus> AHHHH
> 19:54:41 <sipa> promag: god why

> 19:55:45 <jonasschnelli> Also BDB is a compile pitfall

We could make this opt-in in a first release. Then after a few releases make it the default. That way users can still downgrade their node without losing access to the wallet.

It should be possible to `./configure` without BDB, but we'll probably have to ship with BDB 4.8 (at least the ability to read) until the heat death of the universe.

events.body:
I think this issue can be closed. In addition to #18974 the assertion has been replaced with a much safer check:

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/d4ebdceaef130e4b68e5d5db67eecfefd24b4239/src/wallet/rpc/addresses.cpp#L668-L674
yeah, `CHECK_NONFATAL` doesn't crash the program, but it also aborts the current RPC
It would be good to know if this is still an issue with a recent version of Bitcoin Core?
This is no longer an issue in recent versions of Bitcoin Core. We'll close it for now, please feel free to add additional comments or open a new issue if you think that would be helpful.
